title: Network Intrusion Detection System On Mass Parallel Processing Architecture
historical_context: This article discusses advancements in Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS) and their effectiveness in detecting network attacks, particularly in the context of the late 1990s when network security was becoming increasingly critical.
target_audience: Security professionals, network administrators, and researchers interested in intrusion detection systems and their performance metrics.
short_summary: The paper explores the challenges of detecting malicious attacks in real-time using Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS). It proposes a Bayesian Detection Rate (BDR) model implemented in a mass parallel processing environment to enhance detection rates and reduce false positives.
summary:
In this article, Wanderley J. Abreu Jr. addresses the complexities of real-time attack detection in network security, emphasizing the limitations of traditional Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS) in terms of effectiveness, efficiency, and usability. The author introduces a novel approach utilizing a Depth-Search algorithm within a mass parallel processing (MPP) architecture, specifically leveraging a Beowulf Class Cluster. This model aims to improve the Bayesian Detection Rate (BDR), a statistical measure that quantifies the effectiveness of IDS in distinguishing between legitimate and malicious traffic. The paper highlights the mathematical foundations of BDR and provides a detailed analysis of various IDS performance metrics, including false positives and true positives, through experimental results from multiple IDS implementations. 

The experimental setup involved testing several IDS solutions, including SNORT and Cisco NetRanger, against a prototype developed in the MPP environment. The results indicated that the prototype achieved the highest BDR, demonstrating the potential of parallel processing in enhancing IDS capabilities. The author concludes that while this approach does not eliminate false positives entirely, it represents a significant step toward improving the reliability of intrusion detection systems, encouraging further exploration and development in this critical area of cybersecurity.
